text: Okay, the tape is rolling. You don't go to conventions. I noticed in Locust that you finally went to one. I didn't regard that as a convention. Okay, would you just prefer not to meet the fans personally, or is it just kind of you're happy where you're doing, you don't especially like to travel? No, it's a very simple answer that nobody believes. I don't like to travel. Way, way back, I was born in England. I lived a year in Spain. I came to this country until I was a teenager. I never spent more than two years in any one place. I finally spent four years. That was at boarding school in high school. And when I finally got married and settled down, I said, I don't want to move. Well, I was eligible for the draft. I got moved again in the Army, you know, two years back and forth. But when I finally got where I wanted to be, which was warm, it was in Florida, so I settle down and I don't like to move. I just don't do it voluntarily. I'm too used to being uprooted in childhood, so that it's just a dislike for travel. Locally I go and I address the classes of my daughters in school. I don't have any trouble with this. It does take time, and, of course, my time is valuable, but I like to meet people, especially when they're talking about my work. That's all. It's easy to do. But going to a convention would mean, oh, a week or so of my time. That is, I would have to prepare. I would have to get an airplane or drive. I would have to come back. I would have to catch up on my sleep. I mean, all in all, it would be about a week gone even if it were only a three-day convention. When you figure the preparation time and the recovery time and the travel time, a week of my time these days is worth a couple thousand dollars. and I have to think, is this worth this amount to me to go and meet a few people? Well, it depends on the people. I went to this SF Research Association meeting in Kansas for two reasons. One, I wanted to give my other daughter some experience. I mentioned I'd taken one daughter when she was 18, well, when she was 12, it was her turn to go somewhere and do something, get a ride in the airplane, have some experience away from home that was really meaningful. but also they happen to have at that meeting Theodore Sturgeon whose work I've admired since I started reading science fiction they had Frederick Poe who I think may be the best writer in the genre today they had Jack Williamson who was the author of the very first science fiction novel in the first magazine I read introduced they had James Gunn who wrote one of my favorite all time stories In other words, they had about four people there whose work I had really admired. And that was enough to make me, well, if I could meet them all at one time, you see, that made it pay. I went there to meet the people. I did meet them. I complimented them on their work. People asked me for autographs. I never asked. I don't care about signatures, but I took Sturgeon's More Than Human, my 35-cent copy, battered and dates from the 50s, brought it to him, asked him to sign it. It's the only autograph I ever thought or probably ever will seek, simply as a gesture because of admiration for this man's work. So I went. I didn't regard it as a convention. I guess it took on some convention aspects, but I went because it was a meeting where several people I wanted to meet were. I did meet them. Now that I've met them, I don't need to meet them again, and I'd probably be years before I go anywhere again. your statement at the first saying how much money would lose in a week prompted one of our people to ask do you do anything for relaxation so i'll broaden the question what kind of schedule do you work five days seven days a week how many hours a day people often ask me that and i have a standard answer i work all the time that my family will let me i see we have Horses and dogs feed the horses. Chores in the morning take half an hour before. I get up at six and about a quarter or seven. Then I can settle down to my breakfast. So that I don't have all the time of the day. I get about six hours a day, seven days a week. So it comes out close to a 40-hour week working time. I try to read a little around the edges. And if I have to answer correspondence, it comes out of that time. and the rest of the time has taken just in the business of living, of with horses and just reading the mail that comes in, eating and so on. So that even so, I'm fairly well paid now. This is a recent vintage. I mean, I earn a lot more now than I used to. You'll forget that I sold my first story in 1962. It was published in 1963. I earned $20 for it. My first year of writing, I earned $160. So I had all those lean years before I worked up the fat years, where now I do earn a good amount I regarded as balancing out the earlier years. If you took my whole career as a writer, it would not be such a phenomenal income, just that I didn't get it earlier and then I do get it now. But, of course, if I go somewhere now, it comes out of what I'm earning now so that's the way I have to figure it. Any chance with your schedule and with the number of books you've written lately you could get burned down on writing? Well, I wondered when, did you see my novel Viscous Circle in the author's notes? Yes, I read that. That's about as close as I've come, and that was an illness. That I was trying to write a novel and I had a month-long fever, and I wasn't suffering pain, but always with the illness. You know, I don't know where it's going. The doctor couldn't do anything. I mean, you know, is this leading to death, or is it just a minor thing? I had no way of knowing. It reacquainted me with my own mortality, and somewhat shook me up, and I just didn't see the world the same way after that. And so I had to take stock and say, what do I really want to do? And I had serious doubt whether I wanted to continue to write science fiction. That would extend to fantasy also. The thing about fantasy is so easy and so much fun that while I'm in doubt, I can simply do it and make money. I didn't take nearly as much of a conscious decision there because my guts aren't in the fantasy so much. It is less important to me. It's more important financially, but it's less important in terms of my life's work. See what I mean? So I just had to think about it. But as it turned out, when I found a way to stretch the boundaries to include the new themes that I wanted to work on with inside the genre of science fiction, then it's fine, and I go right ahead and write. So at Burnout, I don't think so. I don't suffer from writer's block, and I doubt that I'll suffer from burnout. I still have more ideas to write than I have time to write. I have a couple other projects I want to do, and I can't make time for them. I'm so busy with the paying writing. It appears that along in late 1977, I guess when the cluster books came out and then A Spell for Chameleon was pretty soon after that, that you just exploded as far as your productivity. You'd put up, oh, one or two novels a year for the previous years, and then all of a sudden just a whole lot of novels. What happened then? That's not actually true. You see, I mentioned before I was getting blacklisted. I could only sell a portion of what I wrote. I was writing it. I piled up eight novels unsold so that in the 70s, say 50% of my output was getting into print. But when I finally got through that, I finally became apparent to some of these publishers that I was the one that was right, you see. See, the word was being spread by the blacklisters how difficult a writer I was to deal with and don't deal with this guy and so on. It's just nothing but trouble. When I finally, when that passed and I got to working with editors who knew me personally and knew it wasn't so, then I could sell everything I wrote. So now you're seeing everything I write, and it looks like an explosion, but I always was writing at that pace. I just couldn't get it into print. I still have several novels. I'm sold, and I have stories. I don't write them anymore, but at one point I assembled a whole volume, over 100,000 words, just of my own soul stories. Put it together, I called it Anthonology, a pun on my name in Anthology. Tried to sell it that way, couldn't. So the answer is you're just seeing my work. Now actually I probably am more productive now than I was, but that's not a case of doing three times as much, it's a case of doing perhaps 50% more. Over the years, I've gotten more experience so that I'm just more efficient at writing. I also have more time. My daughters are now teenagers instead of in the twos and threes, and it takes me less time. I don't need to worry about taking care of them. They're off at school, and I have time to write so that my situation has gradually changed. All right, let's see. I've lost track again. Did I answer your question? Yeah, that pretty much answers that. It really wasn't an explosion. An explosion is more apparent than real. I do do about a third of a million words a year, but I always was a fairly prolific writer. I'm a slow writer, but I write all the time so that I get a lot done. Do you type your first draft or handwrite it and then type it or what? Handwrite it. And that dates from when my—I used to type it back in the 1960s, but when my first child was born in 1967, my wife was out working because I didn't learn enough writing to support us. And so I took care of my baby girl, changing her diapers and all this. And that played havoc with my writing, because I couldn't settle down at a typewriter. she was hyperactive, and she wouldn't let me out of her sight. So for a while I tried typing, having the, I forget what you call it, a bassinet sort of little cradle I put in my lap, and as long as I typed, she would be satisfied. But then if I stopped to think, she would wake up and start fussing. So I had to shift from the typewriter. I couldn't work that way. So I went to a pencil and clipboard, and I could literally drop the clipboard and grab her before she hit the ground if she was falling. Once she got over that stage, I found it so much more useful to be able to write with a clipboard that I just continued, because now I write, my wife drives, and I simply sit there and write. I can't read while driving, I get car sick. But I don't have to see, I don't have to read what I'm writing, you see, I just need to see my place so I can write while driving. So on a clipboard, when I went to Kansas, I wrote several hundred words in the air, you know, writing in the airplane. I just had my clipboard there. It would be hard to do with a typewriter. So it was just so versatile that I just continued it, and now I do all of my writing in pencil on the clipboard. Then for the second draft, I type it, get an idea of what I have, and then I type it again for the form of submission draft. My creative work is done in pencil now. You seem to stick almost completely to novels. You don't seem to have had as many short stories as a lot of people, and you do write the novels. Are you comfortable in a short story form as well? This is another change that was dictated by economics. I was comfortable in the short story form and in the novelette form. I only sold one out of four that I did, and that was when I was earning $1,000 a year from writing. I mean, it wasn't enough. Inflation has changed things. This is back in the 60s, but I needed more than that. I hear this interference again. You can hear me? Yeah, I can hear you fine. I think we'll be able to filter it out, so just go on. I had to learn to do novels. They were not my natural form. I had a great deal of difficulty. I had to work. My career has really gone through a stair-step series of things I described, shifting to the pencil and paper, so I could keep on working. Well, learning to do the novel, I did it because it was the only way I would be able to earn my living. And unless I could eventually earn my living in writing, I couldn't afford to continue doing it. I mean, my wife was working to support me. That's okay. She understood. But I wanted to get on my feet and not be dependent. dependent, you might say, forever. Of course, later on, when I started earning more, her full income was going just to pay the tax on mine. She finally had to quit working. She couldn't afford to, really. But in the early days, it wasn't that way. So I was able to support my family once I shifted to novels. But the first novel that I got into print, 2nd, the phone, was very meticulously pieced together in much smaller elements. It actually divides up into about 36 small parts, carefully put together, because I couldn't just start at the beginning and do a novel through to the end. The second one I worked on was this Arabian Night's Fantasy adaptation of Hassan. I had the storyline there from the classic story you see, so it was as though somebody else had designed it i collaborated with a well couldn't even say a dead man i mean this story had been in the uh circulation for many centuries uh i did a couple of collaborations with other people and finally with my novel macroscope i did one big novel unified all the way through it was always conceived as a big novel and after that i knew i had mastered the novel form i didn't worry about it anymore but that's it was hard the novel was not my natural form I guess it is now but I had to acquire that taste had I had my own way I would have stayed in the stories and the novelettes but again so much of my life has been dictated by economic considerations I wish it were not so I would rather have been the kind of writer that the critics applaud or highly literary writer that doesn't have to worry about, uh, things like food and rent, mortgage, but, uh, I always have had to consider the economic aspect. So it was economics that put me into novels. Once I got there, I found I liked it. And now, uh, I have really very little interest. Um, I did last month do a story upon request, a fantasy story before that time, I think I'd done 15 novels in the 100,000 word category. And then, purely as another fanzine, an amateur magazine, had asked for 50-word stories. That's 50 words, half a hundred. I did three of those. So I did 100,000 words for 50 words and nothing in between for the past five or six years. you mentioned a while ago that you had gotten your bachelor's degree in writing when did you at what point in your life did you decide to be a writer when i was two years in college uh at 1954 i had i'd gone through i said it was eight years it started with six years it started i'd taken courses through four years of high school and through two years of college and decided what I wanted to major in, I said, I really can't do it in art, and I'm not good enough. You see, the difference between a commercial, somebody can sell as art. I mean, I was a good artist for the average man on the street, but to sell it, I just didn't think I was that good. I said, well, then what am I going to do? I've got a college education to complete here. I have to choose a major, do something important. So, I went to writing. I really, I felt maybe I had something to say, and I went ahead and tried it, finished out. I wrote a novel for my graduating thesis, never published. And that was the point of decision. I had to decide it in order to finish college. Did decide it. Never regretted it, actually. It turned out, I've made many wrong decisions. This turned out to be one of the right decisions. What influenced you to write science fiction instead of mysteries or porn or romance? What I read was science fiction, it was the one genre that I was conversant in. From the time I was 13 I first discovered Astounding Science Fiction Magazine called Astounding in those days, got hooked into it, and what I did for entertainment, it was science fiction, it was a whole different world, multiple worlds, each one of them better than the one I knew. And so that when I thought about writing, I said if I go to some other genre that I'm not familiar with, I'll make all these mistakes. Whereas in science fiction, I knew that what I did was original because I had read everything in the field. Now, today you can't do that. There's so much more published. But back in those days, there was astounding science fiction. There was galaxy. There was fantasy and science fiction. And there was amazing stories. And that was about it. That was about all. You read four monthly or bi-monthly magazines, there was not much in the paperbacks. They were just starting up then. Valentine Books was just starting a program with paperback novels, so that it was possible to keep up with the entire field, and I did, then. So I knew it. I got into what was familiar, and never left it. As I said now, I tried to leave it, and I'm unable to. How did you break into science fiction then? You started writing it. How long did it take you to break in? Okay, I think I answered that. It took me eight years of writing. Okay. Do you keep up with science fiction now with what's coming out, or any small fraction of it? I try to. I try to. I'm a slow reader. I read at about 150 words a minute. It has to do with my education and follow-ups and so on. I got locked into a slow read I can read faster But when I do I don't enjoy it And I don't have any retention I don't really understand it So I have to be very choosy on what I read Because most of my waking time Has taken up writing And I read slowly So I select, I look at novels I see what's winning awards I read reviews Try to see what might interest me A lot of what I read is for research And so I try to keep up But I only read a very, very small fraction of what's published, and often for perhaps the wrong reasons. I've read one novel, for example, by Gene Wolfe. I don't know if you're familiar with him. Oh, I'm very familiar with him. Okay, he's regarded in the brighter circles as one of the best writers in the genre. Well, that's not why I read the first of his Torture novels. was because it happened to be running very closely parallel to one of mine in sales. And I was curious, what is this one that I keep running next with? You know, what's it like? Is it like mine? So I read it and then said, hey, this guy is a good writer. But it was that, you might say, that accidental. I just don't have time to read the whole field. If I know that somebody's good, I will read to see for myself. But the fact is there are more good writers now than I can keep up with in many people whose work I would enjoy, but I just don't have the time to read them, which I regret. Perhaps if I were a fast reader, but I took a speed reading course once and they didn't know what they were doing. They didn't teach me anything. So between the limitation of time and the slowness, I'm always reading something. and I will, in the course of a year, I'll read 20 or 30 novels. But I know other people, they may read that much, you know, in a month. Of course, they're not trying to write novels at the same time. So I try to keep up with the important figures of the day. And some, June Wolf was one, right now I'm reading a Larry Niven novel called Dream Park just to keep up with what Larry Niven is doing, because he's more or less one of my contemporaries. He broke into writing it about the same time I did. That sort of thing. I wish I were. I can't regard myself as being well-educated in the field now because of the smallness of the amount that I read. Phone was your first novel, as you mentioned, a while ago, and it was pretty popular. I don't know what the sales were, but it was nominated, was it for both awards? I know it was for at least one of them. It came in third for the Nebula and it came in third for the Hugo. Surely that must have helped give you a boost, just a middle boost for your first novel to do that well. Well, yes and no. I thought it would, but that was the publisher. That was Valentine Books. They gave me dishonest reports. I was paid $1,500 for that novel and it had sales in England and in France and in Holland and they showed me that the novel was far from earning out its advance. Well, now money was worth more in those days than now but these days well the last novel I had in the first two months of publication it earned out $18,000 and I don't think I've changed that much. They were not giving the honest statements and I got the evidence to prove it and I didn't well I got the money but I also got blacklisted so that I never had accurate statistics on how well that did. It may have done well but the sales statistics I got showed that it sold maybe 45,000 copies and went dead. I don't believe them, but that's all the evidence I have. Then in the next year's afterphone, you wrote, I guess the Battle Circle novels were the next ones, or at least the first couple of those. Is that correct? Yes, the order I wrote them and the order they were published are not necessarily the same. The first of the Battle Circle novels was Solved the Rope, and that was done so I could enter a contest. Pyramid had this $5,000 contest. Good money in those days. I entered this novel and it won. And then later on, I did a sequel to it, and Pyramid bounced it. They wrote me this fancy letter saying, we wish we could tell you how much we like this novel and that we want to publish it, but we don't. And they sent it back so that it had to be published by a different publisher, who then rejected the third novel in the series. That was Bantam. And so three novels there. Finally, Avon got them, put them all together, and it's been pretty successful ever since. And Nick the Sword never was published by itself in the States, was it? It was, but it was in England, never in this country. Bantam Books bought it and wrote it off. Do you know what I mean by writing it off? Right. They bought it, they paid for it, and they refused to publish it. Apparently it was too violent for them. It was a violent novel, although I wish they'd paid attention to the theme, which was vengeance and the futility of vengeance. I had something to say about vengeance there, and I feel I did a good job at showing what it's like. If you live a life that's based on vengeance, this is what it's going to be like. But nobody ever commented on it. I never got any fan letters. Nobody ever understood that. And the publisher, having bought it, had to change the editors and wrote it off. And so I'm glad that Avon finally did put it into print. Macroscope, you feel, was your first crowning achievement where you thought you had learned to write novels finally? Yes, after that I was confident that I could do it. It was 195,000 words long. I said, I can do that, I can do any length. And I thought it was the major novel of my career until I did Tarot. I still regard it as the second major novel. Did you get fan mail on Macroscope or continue to? Yes, I've had quite a bit over the years. Many people have written to admire it. Macroscope had a problem. I thought that if novels like Thone were placing thirds on the Hugo and the Nebula, what would a novel like Macroscope, which I regard as a much more important work? It wasn't permitted on the ballot at all. Yes, I had a lot of trouble. The publishers would distribute novels to the Science Fiction Writers of America, SFWA. And I got my publisher, Avon, to agree to distribute this novel to them so that people could read it. The membership were expecting the novel to be distributed. the publisher followed up and sent out the novel so that it arrived about a month after the nominations ballot had closed. I got several letters from people saying, look, I know this is a great novel. I'll probably read it and like it and nominate it, but where is it? Well, the publisher had not distributed it. So that I then wrote to the president of SFWA, who was Gordon Dixon, and said, Look, I believe that I've written a major novel of my career. My other ones have been placing high. I feel that if this novel were given a fair chance to be nominated, it would make the ballot. So it wasn't your fault that it didn't, but will you permit writing a vote on the ballot since the ballot was closed? And he wrote back and said no. So I think had they, see, once it was distributed, people could read it and nominate it, but the nominations were closed. So if a write-in had been permitted, I think it could have made the ballot. But Gordon Dixon refused to allow a write-in, and so it was not permitted to compete. And that's it. It went nowhere. A major novel of the first decade of my writing existence, it did make the Hugo ballot. It came in third on the Hugo. The problem there is that for about 10 years, the winner of the Nebula Bout was almost automatically the winner of the Hugo. And mine was not even on the Nebula Bout, so a lot of people didn't bother to read it. I'm pleased that it did come up from nowhere. It was the only novel that made the Hugo Bout that hadn't been on the Nebula Bout. So it's like, you know, if you were in a race and everybody else took off and you came in two minutes later on this 100-yard dash and you have to start to compete, if you get so you can even play, you're doing pretty well. So I feel that the novel did pretty well considering, and SFWA published what amounted to an apology for it later on. They had their collection of Nebula Award winners discussed the novels in them, discussed all the novels on the ballot, plus one, that is, plus Macroscope, more or less apologetically, trying to explain why it hadn't been on the ballot. And that was it. I was not pleased. I felt that they should have permitted a writing ballot so that my novel had a chance at least to compete, but they did not. Okay. We'll ask you one last question, then. Why do you use the nom de plume, Piers Anthony, instead of your real last name. I decided on that before I ever sold a thing. And it said supposing I write, and just supposing I'm successful, and just supposing I get to be famous. So all this was an awful lot of supposing. I mean, I hadn't even sold anything. I'd been trying for several years and hadn't. I'd heard about writers such as John D. MacDonald, a mystery writer, and he had to move several times because people would come in and just drop in. They would assume that he had nothing better to do than to talk with every fan that dropped in on his address. And so he would have to move so his address would be lost. It would take him two or three years to find him, and then they'd take up his time again. Why have this happened to me, if I ever get that well-known? The answer was to use the pen name. So I set up with the pen name from the outset, and it has protected me. I get a lot of fan mail. It goes to the publisher. I don't get many people dropping in on me because they can't find me. They can look up in the phone book. I don't know, maybe there's somebody locally killed, Anthony, that keeps getting people dropping in on him. It's not me, you see. So I have protected myself. If I want someone to know who I am, I can tell them. But the stranger that just says, Hey, gee, there's this writer, I think I'll drop in on him, he is unable to find me. And so now I'm beginning to approach the sort of success that the pseudonym was prepared for. I really never thought I would get there. It was just saying suppose. And I planned well. I'm having more success than I really believed I would have. And now my pen name is serving to protect me, to protect my time, really. Not that I mind talking with people, but, you know, there would be a lot of people that would just like to come. If there's a writer there, they won't even have read anything by that author. They say, gee, that's a writer, I'll go talk to him. But I don't need that sort of thing. I'm willing to talk to people that have read my works, that want to talk to me, ask me intelligent questions. People more like you, you see. I'm not willing to talk to the man off the street who just has heard that I'm a writer. He doesn't even know what I'm writing about. But if there's a writer, he just wants to go and talk to him and take up his time. So that's the reason, again, a rather commercial reason, if you will. but I think effective. I'm very glad that your plans, your carefully worked out plans, were worth it. That's nice. I hate to have it sound so negative, but actually now I do need to protect my time. Of course. Well, sir, we appreciate the time you spent with us. It's been very enlightening. I hope you can digest it down. Oh, yeah. A lot of talking here, which is the danger, and you may have trouble getting it down to your little five-minute segments. Well, that's going to be the hard part, but again, it's much easier to have to cut and that sort of thing than it is to try to stretch. Because some people just are a little bit more reticent. Some of the people that we talk to are actually a little bit shy, which I can understand and are not confident that their answers are. I'm not an English teacher. I mean, I've been in front of classes and so on, so it's not a problem. Okay, great. Well, we sure look forward to whatever else you put out. Well, I hope it works out, and I hope your listeners like it. Great. We sure appreciate your talking to us, and we'll get you copies of the programs. I imagine it'll be about a month and a half or so, but we will get them to you. And thanks again. Enjoyed it very much. Okay, good night now.

segments.text: Okay, the tape is rolling.
You don't go to conventions.
I noticed in Locust that you finally went to one.
I didn't regard that as a convention.
Okay, would you just prefer not to meet the fans personally,
or is it just kind of you're happy where you're doing,
you don't especially like to travel?
No, it's a very simple answer that nobody believes.
I don't like to travel.
Way, way back, I was born in England.
I lived a year in Spain.
I came to this country until I was a teenager.
I never spent more than two years in any one place.
I finally spent four years.
That was at boarding school in high school.
And when I finally got married and settled down, I said, I don't want to move.
Well, I was eligible for the draft.
I got moved again in the Army, you know, two years back and forth.
But when I finally got where I wanted to be, which was warm, it was in Florida,
so I settle down and I don't like to move.
I just don't do it voluntarily.
I'm too used to being uprooted in childhood,
so that it's just a dislike for travel.
Locally I go and I address the classes of my daughters in school.
I don't have any trouble with this.
It does take time, and, of course, my time is valuable,
but I like to meet people, especially when they're talking about my work.
That's all. It's easy to do.
But going to a convention would mean, oh, a week or so of my time.
That is, I would have to prepare.
I would have to get an airplane or drive.
I would have to come back.
I would have to catch up on my sleep.
I mean, all in all, it would be about a week gone even if it were only a three-day convention.
When you figure the preparation time and the recovery time and the travel time,
a week of my time these days is worth a couple thousand dollars.
and I have to think, is this worth this amount to me to go and meet a few people?
Well, it depends on the people.
I went to this SF Research Association meeting in Kansas for two reasons.
One, I wanted to give my other daughter some experience.
I mentioned I'd taken one daughter when she was 18, well, when she was 12,
it was her turn to go somewhere and do something, get a ride in the airplane,
have some experience away from home that was really meaningful.
but also they happen to have at that meeting
Theodore Sturgeon
whose work I've admired
since I started reading science fiction
they had
Frederick Poe who I think may be
the best writer in the genre
today
they had Jack Williamson who was the author
of the very first science fiction novel
in the first magazine I read
introduced
they had James Gunn who wrote
one of my favorite
all time stories
In other words, they had about four people there whose work I had really admired.
And that was enough to make me, well, if I could meet them all at one time, you see, that made it pay.
I went there to meet the people.
I did meet them.
I complimented them on their work.
People asked me for autographs.
I never asked.
I don't care about signatures, but I took Sturgeon's More Than Human, my 35-cent copy,
battered and dates from the 50s, brought it to him, asked him to sign it.
It's the only autograph I ever thought or probably ever will seek,
simply as a gesture because of admiration for this man's work.
So I went.
I didn't regard it as a convention.
I guess it took on some convention aspects,
but I went because it was a meeting where several people I wanted to meet were.
I did meet them.
Now that I've met them, I don't need to meet them again,
and I'd probably be years before I go anywhere again.
your statement at the first saying how much money would lose in a week prompted one of our
people to ask do you do anything for relaxation so i'll broaden the question
what kind of schedule do you work five days seven days a week how many hours a day people often ask
me that and i have a standard answer i work all the time that my family will let me i see we have
Horses and dogs feed the horses.
Chores in the morning take half an hour before.
I get up at six and about a quarter or seven.
Then I can settle down to my breakfast.
So that I don't have all the time of the day.
I get about six hours a day, seven days a week.
So it comes out close to a 40-hour week working time.
I try to read a little around the edges.
And if I have to answer correspondence, it comes out of that time.
and the rest of the time has taken just in the business of living,
of with horses and just reading the mail that comes in, eating and so on.
So that even so, I'm fairly well paid now.
This is a recent vintage.
I mean, I earn a lot more now than I used to.
You'll forget that I sold my first story in 1962.
It was published in 1963.
I earned $20 for it.
My first year of writing,
I earned $160.
So I had all those lean years
before I worked up
the fat years,
where now I do earn a good amount
I regarded as balancing out
the earlier years.
If you took my whole career
as a writer,
it would not be such
a phenomenal income,
just that I didn't get it earlier
and then I do get it now.
But, of course,
if I go somewhere now,
it comes out of what I'm earning now
so that's the way I have to figure it.
Any chance with your schedule
and with the number of books you've written lately
you could get burned down on writing?
Well, I wondered when,
did you see my novel Viscous Circle
in the author's notes?
Yes, I read that.
That's about as close as I've come,
and that was an illness.
That I was trying to write a novel
and I had a month-long fever,
and I wasn't suffering pain,
but always with the illness.
You know, I don't know where it's going.
The doctor couldn't do anything.
I mean, you know, is this leading to death,
or is it just a minor thing?
I had no way of knowing.
It reacquainted me with my own mortality,
and somewhat shook me up,
and I just didn't see the world the same way after that.
And so I had to take stock and say,
what do I really want to do?
And I had serious doubt
whether I wanted to continue to write science fiction.
That would extend to fantasy also.
The thing about fantasy is so easy and so much fun
that while I'm in doubt, I can simply do it and make money.
I didn't take nearly as much of a conscious decision there
because my guts aren't in the fantasy so much.
It is less important to me.
It's more important financially,
but it's less important in terms of my life's work.
See what I mean?
So I just had to think about it.
But as it turned out, when I found a way to stretch the boundaries to include the new themes that I wanted to work on with inside the genre of science fiction,
then it's fine, and I go right ahead and write.
So at Burnout, I don't think so.
I don't suffer from writer's block, and I doubt that I'll suffer from burnout.
I still have more ideas to write than I have time to write.
I have a couple other projects I want to do, and I can't make time for them.
I'm so busy with the paying writing.
It appears that along in late 1977, I guess when the cluster books came out
and then A Spell for Chameleon was pretty soon after that,
that you just exploded as far as your productivity.
You'd put up, oh, one or two novels a year for the previous years,
and then all of a sudden just a whole lot of novels.
What happened then?
That's not actually true.
You see, I mentioned before I was getting blacklisted.
I could only sell a portion of what I wrote.
I was writing it.
I piled up eight novels unsold so that in the 70s, say 50% of my output was getting into print.
But when I finally got through that, I finally became apparent to some of these publishers
that I was the one that was right, you see.
See, the word was being spread by the blacklisters how difficult a writer I was to deal with
and don't deal with this guy and so on.
It's just nothing but trouble.
When I finally, when that passed
and I got to working with editors
who knew me personally and knew it wasn't so,
then I could sell everything I wrote.
So now you're seeing everything I write,
and it looks like an explosion,
but I always was writing at that pace.
I just couldn't get it into print.
I still have several novels.
I'm sold, and I have stories.
I don't write them anymore,
but at one point I assembled a whole volume, over 100,000 words, just of my own soul stories.
Put it together, I called it Anthonology, a pun on my name in Anthology.
Tried to sell it that way, couldn't.
So the answer is you're just seeing my work.
Now actually I probably am more productive now than I was,
but that's not a case of doing three times as much, it's a case of doing perhaps 50% more.
Over the years, I've gotten more experience
so that I'm just more efficient at writing.
I also have more time.
My daughters are now teenagers
instead of in the twos and threes,
and it takes me less time.
I don't need to worry about taking care of them.
They're off at school,
and I have time to write
so that my situation has gradually changed.
All right, let's see.
I've lost track again.
Did I answer your question?
Yeah, that pretty much answers that.
It really wasn't an explosion.
An explosion is more apparent than real.
I do do about a third of a million words a year,
but I always was a fairly prolific writer.
I'm a slow writer, but I write all the time
so that I get a lot done.
Do you type your first draft
or handwrite it and then type it or what?
Handwrite it.
And that dates from when my—I used to type it back in the 1960s,
but when my first child was born in 1967,
my wife was out working because I didn't learn enough writing to support us.
And so I took care of my baby girl, changing her diapers and all this.
And that played havoc with my writing, because I couldn't settle down at a typewriter.
she was hyperactive, and she wouldn't let me out of her sight.
So for a while I tried typing, having the, I forget what you call it, a bassinet sort of little cradle I put in my lap,
and as long as I typed, she would be satisfied.
But then if I stopped to think, she would wake up and start fussing.
So I had to shift from the typewriter.
I couldn't work that way.
So I went to a pencil and clipboard,
and I could literally drop the clipboard and grab her
before she hit the ground if she was falling.
Once she got over that stage,
I found it so much more useful to be able to write with a clipboard
that I just continued, because now I write,
my wife drives, and I simply sit there and write.
I can't read while driving, I get car sick.
But I don't have to see, I don't have to read what I'm writing, you see,
I just need to see my place so I can write while driving.
So on a clipboard, when I went to Kansas,
I wrote several hundred words in the air,
you know, writing in the airplane.
I just had my clipboard there.
It would be hard to do with a typewriter.
So it was just so versatile that I just continued it,
and now I do all of my writing in pencil on the clipboard.
Then for the second draft, I type it,
get an idea of what I have,
and then I type it again for the form of submission draft.
My creative work is done in pencil now.
You seem to stick almost completely to novels.
You don't seem to have had as many short stories as a lot of people,
and you do write the novels.
Are you comfortable in a short story form as well?
This is another change that was dictated by economics.
I was comfortable in the short story form and in the novelette form.
I only sold one out of four that I did,
and that was when I was earning $1,000 a year from writing.
I mean, it wasn't enough.
Inflation has changed things.
This is back in the 60s, but I needed more than that.
I hear this interference again.
You can hear me?
Yeah, I can hear you fine.
I think we'll be able to filter it out, so just go on.
I had to learn to do novels.
They were not my natural form.
I had a great deal of difficulty.
I had to work.
My career has really gone through a stair-step series of things I described,
shifting to the pencil and paper, so I could keep on working.
Well, learning to do the novel,
I did it because it was the only way I would be able to earn my living.
And unless I could eventually earn my living in writing,
I couldn't afford to continue doing it.
I mean, my wife was working to support me.
That's okay.
She understood.
But I wanted to get on my feet and not be dependent.
dependent, you might say, forever. Of course, later on, when I started earning more, her
full income was going just to pay the tax on mine. She finally had to quit working.
She couldn't afford to, really. But in the early days, it wasn't that way. So I was able
to support my family once I shifted to novels. But the first novel that I got into print,
2nd, the phone, was very meticulously pieced together in much smaller elements.
It actually divides up into about 36 small parts, carefully put together, because I couldn't
just start at the beginning and do a novel through to the end.
The second one I worked on was this Arabian Night's Fantasy adaptation of Hassan.
I had the storyline there from the classic story you see, so it was as though somebody
else had designed it i collaborated with a well couldn't even say a dead man i mean this story
had been in the uh circulation for many centuries uh i did a couple of collaborations with other
people and finally with my novel macroscope i did one big novel unified all the way through
it was always conceived as a big novel and after that i knew i had mastered the novel form i didn't
worry about it anymore
but that's
it was hard
the novel was not
my natural form
I guess it is now
but I had to
acquire that taste
had I had my own way
I would have stayed
in the stories
and the novelettes
but again
so much
of my life
has been dictated
by economic
considerations
I wish it were
not so
I would rather
have been
the kind of
writer
that the critics
applaud
or highly
literary
writer that doesn't have to worry about, uh, things like food and rent, mortgage, but,
uh, I always have had to consider the economic aspect. So it was economics that put me into
novels. Once I got there, I found I liked it. And now, uh, I have really very little
interest. Um, I did last month do a story upon request, a fantasy story before that
time, I think I'd done 15 novels in the 100,000 word category. And then, purely as another
fanzine, an amateur magazine, had asked for 50-word stories. That's 50 words, half a
hundred. I did three of those. So I did 100,000 words for 50 words and nothing in between for
the past five or six years.
you mentioned a while ago that you had gotten your bachelor's degree in writing
when did you at what point in your life did you decide to be a writer
when i was two years in college uh at 1954 i had i'd gone through i said it was eight years
it started with six years it started i'd taken courses through four years of high school
and through two years of college
and decided what I wanted to major in,
I said, I really can't do it in art,
and I'm not good enough.
You see, the difference between a commercial,
somebody can sell as art.
I mean, I was a good artist
for the average man on the street,
but to sell it,
I just didn't think I was that good.
I said, well, then what am I going to do?
I've got a college education to complete here.
I have to choose a major,
do something important.
So, I went to writing.
I really, I felt maybe I had something to say, and I went ahead and tried it, finished out.
I wrote a novel for my graduating thesis, never published.
And that was the point of decision.
I had to decide it in order to finish college.
Did decide it.
Never regretted it, actually.
It turned out, I've made many wrong decisions.
This turned out to be one of the right decisions.
What influenced you to write science fiction instead of mysteries or porn or romance?
What I read was science fiction, it was the one genre that I was conversant in.
From the time I was 13 I first discovered Astounding Science Fiction Magazine called
Astounding in those days, got hooked into it, and what I did for entertainment, it was
science fiction, it was a whole different world, multiple worlds, each one of them better
than the one I knew.
And so that when I thought about writing,
I said if I go to some other genre
that I'm not familiar with,
I'll make all these mistakes.
Whereas in science fiction,
I knew that what I did was original
because I had read everything in the field.
Now, today you can't do that.
There's so much more published.
But back in those days,
there was astounding science fiction.
There was galaxy.
There was fantasy and science fiction.
And there was amazing stories.
And that was about it.
That was about all.
You read four monthly or bi-monthly magazines,
there was not much in the paperbacks.
They were just starting up then.
Valentine Books was just starting a program
with paperback novels,
so that it was possible to keep up with the entire field,
and I did, then.
So I knew it.
I got into what was familiar,
and never left it.
As I said now, I tried to leave it,
and I'm unable to.
How did you break into science fiction then?
You started writing it.
How long did it take you to break in?
Okay, I think I answered that.
It took me eight years of writing.
Okay.
Do you keep up with science fiction now
with what's coming out,
or any small fraction of it?
I try to.
I try to.
I'm a slow reader.
I read at about 150 words a minute.
It has to do with my education and follow-ups and so on.
I got locked into a slow read
I can read faster
But when I do I don't enjoy it
And I don't have any retention
I don't really understand it
So I have to be very choosy on what I read
Because most of my waking time
Has taken up writing
And I read slowly
So I select, I look at novels
I see what's winning awards
I read reviews
Try to see what might interest me
A lot of what I read is for research
And so I try to keep up
But I only read a very, very small fraction of what's published,
and often for perhaps the wrong reasons.
I've read one novel, for example, by Gene Wolfe.
I don't know if you're familiar with him.
Oh, I'm very familiar with him.
Okay, he's regarded in the brighter circles as one of the best writers in the genre.
Well, that's not why I read the first of his Torture novels.
was because it happened to be running very closely parallel to one of mine in sales.
And I was curious, what is this one that I keep running next with?
You know, what's it like? Is it like mine?
So I read it and then said, hey, this guy is a good writer.
But it was that, you might say, that accidental.
I just don't have time to read the whole field.
If I know that somebody's good, I will read to see for myself.
But the fact is there are more good writers now than I can keep up with
in many people whose work I would enjoy,
but I just don't have the time to read them, which I regret.
Perhaps if I were a fast reader, but I took a speed reading course once
and they didn't know what they were doing.
They didn't teach me anything.
So between the limitation of time and the slowness,
I'm always reading something.
and I will, in the course of a year, I'll read 20 or 30 novels.
But I know other people, they may read that much, you know, in a month.
Of course, they're not trying to write novels at the same time.
So I try to keep up with the important figures of the day.
And some, June Wolf was one,
right now I'm reading a Larry Niven novel called Dream Park
just to keep up with what Larry Niven is doing,
because he's more or less one of my contemporaries.
He broke into writing it about the same time I did.
That sort of thing.
I wish I were.
I can't regard myself as being well-educated in the field now
because of the smallness of the amount that I read.
Phone was your first novel, as you mentioned, a while ago,
and it was pretty popular.
I don't know what the sales were,
but it was nominated,
was it for both awards?
I know it was for at least one of them.
It came in third for the Nebula
and it came in third for the Hugo.
Surely that must have helped give you a boost,
just a middle boost for your first novel
to do that well.
Well, yes and no.
I thought it would,
but that was the publisher.
That was Valentine Books.
They gave me dishonest reports.
I was paid $1,500 for that novel
and it had sales in England
and in France
and in Holland
and they showed me
that the novel was far
from earning out
its advance.
Well,
now money was worth more
in those days
than now
but these days
well the last novel
I had in the first
two months of publication
it earned out $18,000
and I don't think
I've changed that much.
They were not giving
the honest statements
and I got the evidence
to prove it
and I didn't
well I got the money
but I also got blacklisted
so that I never had
accurate statistics
on how well that did.
It may have done well
but the sales statistics I got showed that it sold maybe 45,000 copies and went dead.
I don't believe them, but that's all the evidence I have.
Then in the next year's afterphone, you wrote,
I guess the Battle Circle novels were the next ones,
or at least the first couple of those. Is that correct?
Yes, the order I wrote them and the order they were published
are not necessarily the same.
The first of the Battle Circle novels was Solved the Rope,
and that was done so I could enter a contest.
Pyramid had this $5,000 contest.
Good money in those days.
I entered this novel and it won.
And then later on, I did a sequel to it,
and Pyramid bounced it.
They wrote me this fancy letter saying,
we wish we could tell you how much we like this novel
and that we want to publish it, but we don't.
And they sent it back
so that it had to be published by a different publisher,
who then rejected the third novel in the series.
That was Bantam.
And so three novels there.
Finally, Avon got them, put them all together,
and it's been pretty successful ever since.
And Nick the Sword never was published by itself in the States, was it?
It was, but it was in England, never in this country.
Bantam Books bought it and wrote it off.
Do you know what I mean by writing it off?
Right.
They bought it, they paid for it, and they refused to publish it.
Apparently it was too violent for them.
It was a violent novel, although I wish they'd paid attention to the theme,
which was vengeance and the futility of vengeance.
I had something to say about vengeance there,
and I feel I did a good job at showing what it's like.
If you live a life that's based on vengeance, this is what it's going to be like.
But nobody ever commented on it.
I never got any fan letters.
Nobody ever understood that.
And the publisher, having bought it,
had to change the editors and wrote it off.
And so I'm glad that Avon finally did put it into print.
Macroscope, you feel, was your first crowning achievement
where you thought you had learned to write novels finally?
Yes, after that I was confident that I could do it.
It was 195,000 words long.
I said, I can do that, I can do any length.
And I thought it was the major novel of my career
until I did Tarot.
I still regard it as the second major novel.
Did you get fan mail on Macroscope or continue to?
Yes, I've had quite a bit over the years.
Many people have written to admire it.
Macroscope had a problem.
I thought that if novels like Thone were placing thirds on the Hugo and the Nebula,
what would a novel like Macroscope, which I regard as a much more important work?
It wasn't permitted on the ballot at all.
Yes, I had a lot of trouble.
The publishers would distribute novels to the Science Fiction Writers of America, SFWA.
And I got my publisher, Avon, to agree to distribute this novel to them
so that people could read it.
The membership were expecting the novel to be distributed.
the publisher followed up
and sent out the novel
so that it arrived about a month after
the nominations
ballot had closed.
I got several letters from people saying,
look, I know this is a great novel.
I'll probably read it and like it and nominate it,
but where is it?
Well, the publisher had not
distributed it.
So that
I then wrote
to the
president of SFWA, who was Gordon Dixon, and said,
Look, I believe that I've written a major novel of my career.
My other ones have been placing high.
I feel that if this novel were given a fair chance to be nominated,
it would make the ballot.
So it wasn't your fault that it didn't,
but will you permit writing a vote on the ballot since the ballot was closed?
And he wrote back and said no.
So I think had they, see, once it was distributed,
people could read it and nominate it,
but the nominations were closed.
So if a write-in had been permitted,
I think it could have made the ballot.
But Gordon Dixon refused to allow a write-in,
and so it was not permitted to compete.
And that's it.
It went nowhere.
A major novel of the first decade of my writing existence,
it did make the Hugo ballot.
It came in third on the Hugo.
The problem there is that for about 10 years,
the winner of the Nebula Bout
was almost automatically the winner of the Hugo.
And mine was not even on the Nebula Bout,
so a lot of people didn't bother to read it.
I'm pleased that it did come up from nowhere.
It was the only novel that made the Hugo Bout
that hadn't been on the Nebula Bout.
So it's like, you know, if you were in a race and everybody else took off
and you came in two minutes later on this 100-yard dash and you have to start to compete,
if you get so you can even play, you're doing pretty well.
So I feel that the novel did pretty well considering,
and SFWA published what amounted to an apology for it later on.
They had their collection of Nebula Award winners discussed the novels in them,
discussed all the novels on the ballot,
plus one, that is, plus Macroscope,
more or less apologetically, trying to explain
why it hadn't been on the ballot.
And that was it.
I was not pleased.
I felt that they should have permitted
a writing ballot so that my novel
had a chance at least to compete,
but they did not.
Okay.
We'll ask you one last question, then.
Why do you use the
nom de plume, Piers Anthony,
instead of your real last name.
I decided on that before I ever sold a thing.
And it said supposing I write,
and just supposing I'm successful,
and just supposing I get to be famous.
So all this was an awful lot of supposing.
I mean, I hadn't even sold anything.
I'd been trying for several years and hadn't.
I'd heard about writers such as John D. MacDonald,
a mystery writer,
and he had to move several times
because people would come in and just drop in.
They would assume that he had nothing better to do
than to talk with every fan that dropped in on his address.
And so he would have to move so his address would be lost.
It would take him two or three years to find him,
and then they'd take up his time again.
Why have this happened to me, if I ever get that well-known?
The answer was to use the pen name.
So I set up with the pen name from the outset,
and it has protected me.
I get a lot of fan mail.
It goes to the publisher.
I don't get many people dropping in on me because they can't find me.
They can look up in the phone book.
I don't know, maybe there's somebody locally killed, Anthony,
that keeps getting people dropping in on him.
It's not me, you see.
So I have protected myself.
If I want someone to know who I am, I can tell them.
But the stranger that just says,
Hey, gee, there's this writer, I think I'll drop in on him,
he is unable to find me.
And so now I'm beginning to approach the sort of success
that the pseudonym was prepared for.
I really never thought I would get there.
It was just saying suppose.
And I planned well.
I'm having more success than I really believed I would have.
And now my pen name is serving to protect me,
to protect my time, really.
Not that I mind talking with people,
but, you know, there would be a lot of people
that would just like to come.
If there's a writer there,
they won't even have read anything by that author.
They say, gee, that's a writer, I'll go talk to him.
But I don't need that sort of thing.
I'm willing to talk to people that have read my works, that want to talk to me, ask me intelligent questions.
People more like you, you see.
I'm not willing to talk to the man off the street who just has heard that I'm a writer.
He doesn't even know what I'm writing about.
But if there's a writer, he just wants to go and talk to him and take up his time.
So that's the reason, again, a rather commercial reason, if you will.
but I think effective.
I'm very glad that your plans, your carefully worked out plans, were worth it.
That's nice.
I hate to have it sound so negative, but actually now I do need to protect my time.
Of course.
Well, sir, we appreciate the time you spent with us.
It's been very enlightening.
I hope you can digest it down.
Oh, yeah.
A lot of talking here, which is the danger,
and you may have trouble getting it down to your little five-minute segments.
Well, that's going to be the hard part,
but again, it's much easier to have to cut and that sort of thing than it is to try to stretch.
Because some people just are a little bit more reticent.
Some of the people that we talk to are actually a little bit shy,
which I can understand and are not confident that their answers are.
I'm not an English teacher.
I mean, I've been in front of classes and so on, so it's not a problem.
Okay, great.
Well, we sure look forward to whatever else you put out.
Well, I hope it works out, and I hope your listeners like it.
Great.
We sure appreciate your talking to us, and we'll get you copies of the programs.
I imagine it'll be about a month and a half or so, but we will get them to you.
And thanks again.
Enjoyed it very much.
Okay, good night now.
